content.title: Median Arcuate Ligament Syndrome (MALS)
content.definition: Compression of the celiac artery by the median arcuate ligament (a fibrous arch connecting the diaphragmatic crura) causing postprandial abdominal pain, weight loss, and possibly chronic mesenteric ischemia. Also known as celiac artery compression syndrome or Dunbar syndrome.

key_concepts.description: Median arcuate ligament normally crosses the aorta above the celiac artery origin; in MALS, low ligament or high celiac origin causes compression, especially during expiration
Debated whether symptoms are truly vascular (ischemia) or neurogenic (celiac ganglion compression); many asymptomatic individuals have celiac compression on imaging; patient selection is critical
Young, thin woman with postprandial abdominal pain, food fear, weight loss; symptoms often vague; extensive prior workup often negative; may have epigastric bruit
Epigastric bruit that varies with respiration (increases with expiration); tenderness to palpation; often thin habitus from weight loss
CTA/MRA shows hooked appearance of celiac artery with narrowing at diaphragmatic level, worse with expiration; lateral aortogram during inspiration and expiration is classic
Gastric tonometry (outdated); celiac plexus block may predict surgical response (pain relief suggests neuropathic component); duplex with respiratory maneuvers
Chronic mesenteric ischemia (atherosclerotic), functional dyspepsia, gastroparesis, biliary disease, pancreatitis, psychiatric disorders
Median arcuate ligament release (division of ligament and celiac ganglion fibers) via laparotomy or laparoscopy; may require celiac artery reconstruction if stenosis persists
Stenting alone has high failure rate due to extrinsic compression; may be used after surgical ligament release for residual stenosis
Variable results (50-80% symptom improvement); better outcomes in patients with weight loss, postprandial pain, and positive celiac block; psychiatric comorbidity predicts poor response

learning_objectives: Define MALS and understand the anatomic basis
Know the controversy over true ischemia vs neurogenic pain
Understand treatment options and variable outcomes
clinical_pearls: Classic: young thin woman, postprandial pain, weight loss
Epigastric bruit that changes with respiration is key finding
Many people have celiac compression on imaging without symptoms
Celiac block may predict surgical response
Stenting alone fails (extrinsic compression) - need ligament release first
50-80% symptom improvement - patient selection is critical
common_mistakes: Stenting without ligament release (high failure rate)
Operating on asymptomatic incidental celiac compression
Missing atherosclerotic mesenteric disease as the true cause
